snippet: A federal district court judge rejected a plea bargain deal in a brave bid to curb a little-known extension of federal prosecutors’ very broad power.
abstract: Editorial welcomes decision by federal judge John Kane to reject a plea bargain deal because it waived the defendant's right to appeal to a higher court; contends that such waivers represent a serious threat to the fairness of the judicial process, and asserts that without an appeals court's policing, the system of pleas then looks more like a system of coercion.
lead_paragraph: A federal district court judge rejected a plea bargain deal in a brave bid to curb a little-known extension of federal prosecutors’ very broad power.
